sec.title: Synthesis

boxed-text.p: Reviewing Editor: Christophe Bernard, INSERM & Institut de Neurosciences des SystÃ¨mes

Decisions are customarily a result of the Reviewing Editor and the peer reviewers coming together and discussing their recommendations until a consensus is reached. When revisions are invited, a fact-based synthesis statement explaining their decision and outlining what is needed to prepare a revision will be listed below. The following reviewer(s) agreed to reveal their identity: Jeremy Day, Ophir Shalem.

sec.p: Reviewer 1:

This review highlights recent advances in the use of CRISPR-based approaches in the nervous system. In general it is well written and identifies a number of challenges and opportunities in this emerging area. In addition to covering the use of Cas9 for gene editing in various contexts (e.g., to make a transgenic animal, in dividing cell lines, and in mature differentiated neurons), this review also covers approaches based on catalytically inactive dCas9 strategies for gene regulation or epigenetic editing. The review provides a relatively comprehensive overview of current developments in each area, and the illustrations are top notch and enhance the manuscript. Although several other recent reviews and book chapters exist on the same topic (e.g., PMIDs 31191241, 28018138, 31314232, 29259522, 26656253), most of these are now 2-3 years old. Given the rapidly moving nature of this field, this is a timely and useful review. Nevertheless, I have listed several comments for improvement of the manuscript below.
Major suggestions:

1. This review has a chance to extend beyond ground covered by previous reviews by including coverage of more recently described advances in use of CRISPR to understand the nervous system - for example, targeting Cas9 to screen many different genes implicated in neuropsychiatric or neurodegenerative disease (e.g., PMID 30929901), to trace lineage and development of the nervous system (e.g., PMID 29608178), or to isolate functions of individual genes in specific cell types via integration with scRNA-seq (e.g., DOI: https://doi.org/10.1101/791525). These approaches are likely to capture the interests of readers less familiar with these types of approaches, as opposed to a more straightforward (but less novel) repetition of some of the basic features of the CRISPR system.

2. dCas9 sections cover several mouse lines used for CRISPRa and CRISPRi, but are missing some key citations describing these techniques in other contexts (PMIDs 30699347, 27341390, 30863790, 25849986, and 28111074).

3. Figures 3-7 cover similar conceptual ground in use of dCas9 fusion proteins to modify gene expression or local epigenetic states. I would encourage the authors to combine these into a single figure, which would help to show that these approaches are all variations on the same theme, while also preventing some mental redundancy across figures.

4. Figures 3-4 appear to have been skipped in order - Figure 5 is actually the third figure in the manuscript. Additionally, figures should be referenced in the text at appropriate places to alert the reader to graphical illustrations.

5. Page 22, final paragraph: In discussion of the usefulness of multiplexing several different sgRNAs, it would be important to discuss results from Savell, et al (2019 eNeuro; PMID 30863790) since this paper compared effects of multiple sgRNAs at the same locus and also mixed sgRNAs targeted to different genes.
Minor comments:
1. Page 4, paragraph 2: Typo - âpredominateâ should be âpredominantâ
2. Page 9, second paragraph: Insert period after â... when conjugated to other proteinsâ
3. Page 12, last paragraph: Platt, et al citation repeated twice.
4. Page 15, second paragraph: de Solis, et al., citation should not be in parentheses
5. Page 25, second line: âpredominateâ should be âpredominantâ
Reviewer 2:

This topic of this review, genome-editing in neurons, is important, timely, and a good review that focuses specifically on the challenges of applying CRISPR based perturbations in neuronal cells will be very useful, because while the development and applications of CRISPR associated proteins is covered in many excellent reviews, very few of those focus specifically on editing in neuronal cells. Unfortunately, the current review reads more like âGenome editing in neuroscience researchâ. The sections that discuss genome-editing in the CNS are good. But the review as a whole is quite unfocused, the sections that discuss the general development of CRISPR systems for different applications are highly redundant with other published reviews and the sections that discuss editing in the CNS lacks a few important points of discussion. I suggest a major revision to reorganize the paper and focus much more on the major challenges of neuronal editing for both therapeutic and research applications.
Specific comments:

â¢ About 40-50% of the paper (I did not precisely measure this) discusses general development of CRISPR genetic perturbation systems. This can probably be shortened with references to existing published reviews.

â¢ This review only considers precise editing in neuronal cells mediated by HDR. Other approaches exist especially for research applications. NHEJ mediated editing in non-dividing cells has been demonstrated for gene corrections (PMID: 27851729) and gene tagging (PMID: 31272828). The enzyme Cpf1 is also worth mentioning in this regard as its staggered cutting might enable gene insertions that are independent of HDR. Lastly, methods that do not relay on the generation of a DSB as based editors and the most recent prime editors should be discussed.
â¢ A discussion of the differences in DNA repair pathways in dividing vs. neuronal cells would be useful here.

â¢ Choice of titles for the different sections is a bit confusing, for example after "Genome Editing in the mammalian brain" (which is a similar title to the article title) discusses viral delivery into the brain. This section is preceded by a discussion on RNP delivery. This should all be under a much more extensive discussion on the delivery challenges into the CNS with a separation between clinical and research applications.

â¢ There is an extensive discussion on germline editing for the generation of transgenic animals. If the theme of the article is neuronal editing this seems irrelevant. If this is indeed a review on genome-editing in neuroscience then this section is useful, especially the discussion of rat models which are less discussed in other reviews.
â¢ In the discussion of inducible systems, it is probably worth mentioning this paper: PMID: 25848930 that resulted in a much better sensitivity compared to Tet based systems.

â¢ Especially as this is a review article, the authors should make sure that (1) all statements are backed by citations. (2) All citations are correct. Example of (1): In page 13 the paragraph starting with "While CRISPR-Cas9 has been used to edit a bevy of cell types and tissues..." contains no citations at all. Example of (2): "and gain-of-function (GOF) screens including a recent report of a successful genome-wide screen in the brain (Chow et al., 2017; Cong et al., 2013). - Wrong reference" Cong et al. 2013 does not describe a genome-wide screen.
â¢ PMID: 31422865 should be discussed.
â¢ A summary of the main challenges: delivery, off target activity, immunogenicity of CRISPR proteins, efficiency of precise editing in neurons would be useful to add in the last section.
